newsitem.title: USA: Ron Brown foundation opens fund-raising campaign. [CORRECTED 15:55 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Ron Brown foundation opens fund-raising campaign. [CORRECTED 15:55 GMT]

text.p: The Ronald H. Brown Foundation, founded in honour of the energetic U.S. commerce secretary killed last year in a Croatia (corrects from Bosnia) plane crash, came to his hometown to kick off a national fund-raising campaign.
The hosts of a New York reception Monday told a blue-ribbon crowd that the 9-month-old foundation would also be raising funds in Washington and Atlanta.

From a relatively privileged childhood in predominantly black Harlem, Ron Brown became the only black person so far to chair a major political party and was credited with a major role in Bill Clinton's 1992 presidential victory.
Brown then energised the Department of Commerce by working hard to maximize American exports.
The social goals of the Brown foundation's three divisions were designed to reflect his father's values and achievements, foundation president Michael Brown said.

Business people unfamiliar with different cultures will be able to learn diplomacy and the behaviour recommended for nations of their choice at a Centre for Politics and Commercial Diplomacy, he said.
"Americans are sometimes considered rude when they try to do business in other countries," he told a laughing audience.
The nonpartisan centre will also teach practical political skills for domestic use, drawing on the experience of mayors, congressmen and other elected officials, he said.

The Ronald H. Brown Global Clearinghouse, which first convened last November, will show proprietors of small and medium-sized businesses, especially women and members of minorities, how to overcome hurdles that have prevented them from doing business overseas, Brown said.
That activity will follow his father's policy of "getting people to the table who traditionally did not have a seat," he said.
Finally, a think tank will be inaugurated next year to help business owners from historically disadvantaged groups develop "national and international policy agendas," Brown said.
